Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the participation of U.S.-based researchers in the program "Minimal surfaces and geometric flows,'' co-organized by the principal investigator, to be held January 18-29, 2021 at the Matrix Institute, located on the University of Melbourne's Creswick campus, Victoria, Australia. The first week of the event offers two minicourses in the style of a winter school aimed at junior researchers. The second week is focused on research seminars in the style of a conference, with junior and senior researchers presenting their research. An emphasis is put on the interaction between experts in the area and training opportunities for young researchers.<br/><br/>This program aims to bring together mathematicians from different countries that are currently working on classical and nonlocal geometric problems, with special interest in the study of classification and regularity results for classical and nonlocal minimal surfaces, problems related to spectral analysis of elliptic problems of geometric interest, maximum principles, oscillation theorems, and existence and qualitative properties of solutions to classical and nonlocal geometric flows. The first week consists of minicourses in which junior participants receive a state-of-the-art introduction to this emerging field, with an emphasis on interaction and discussion. During the second week, senior and junior participants will present the latest developments in these areas of research.<br/><br/>https://www.matrix-inst.org.au/events/pminimal-surfaces-and-geometric-flows-interaction-between-the-local-and-the-nonlocal-worlds/<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF funding supported the participation of researchers based in the United States in the program titled "Minimal Surfaces and Geometric Flows: Interaction Between the Local and Nonlocal Worlds." This two-week initiative comprised a workshop during the first week and two mini-courses in the second week.

Traditional subjects in geometric analysis, including minimal surfaces, surfaces with constant mean curvature, curve-shortening flows, mean curvature flows, Gauss curvature flows, among others, were explored during the program. A comprehensive understanding of these topics necessitates the integration of methods from mathematical analysis and differential geometry. The outcomes of such investigations have far-reaching applications in diverse areas, such as phase transitions, moving fronts, free boundary problems, and mathematical biology.

Conversely, there has been a recent upswing in interest regarding nonlocal minimal surfaces and nonlocal geometric flows. The concept of nonlocal perimeter finds applications and establishes connections with various fields, including long-range phase coexistence models, spin models in statistical mechanics, geometric flows, image reconstruction, and nonlocal capillarity models.

Over the two weeks, experts from both domains shared their research, exchanging knowledge and engaging in discussions about new questions and unresolved issues. A key emphasis of the program was to actively involve graduate students and early career researchers in this contemporary research area, fostering ample opportunities for discussion and collaborative work.
